en.value: Here are all the expressions we've just learned:
Select all of the words that could come after "these".
We use "these" and "those" to refer to groups of objects or people. . "These" refers to things that are nearby, and "those" refers to things that are further away.
You can say this when you've chosen what you would like to buy.
Select the numbers from smallest to largest.
We use "that" to refer to things / people that are further away.
Useful phrases for shop scenarios, asking for and giving the price of something - "This, that, these, those"
The house is a centure old.
The last four are easy to remember. You just take the single-digit number and add -teen.
[k]Do you sell|Do you have[/k] any winter clothes?
Select the phrase you hear in the audio.
This means the same as "That comes to £48.50.".
Now we’re going to look at numbers 20 to 100. Notice how with numbers 20 to 90, we add the ending -ty. However, note how 100 doesn't follow this rule!
Read and listen to the expression and key phrase.
I'm looking for... / Do you sell...?
This sentence talks about something / someone that is nearby.
Excuse me, [k]how much is[/k] this shirt?
Those keys are my keys! - Those are my keys!
The supermarket is open until 11 p.m.
Type a phrase which is similar in meaning to "That comes to ...".
Is this bag your bag? - Is this your bag?
It’s pretty straightforward to work out the rest of the numbers, as they follow a pattern.
Select the words in the correct order.
Select all of the words that could come after "that".
Select the word that can replace "jacket".
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
This sentence talks about something / someone that is nearby.
How much do the three coffees come to?
This is a hundred years old house.
This a hundred years old house.
Imagine you've just walked into a shop. Ask the shop assistant for help with finding something.
When telling you how much you need to pay, the shop assistant might say:
How much does the bill come to?
Wonderful. [k]I'll take[/k] it. And this bag as well, please.

"This", "that", "these" and "those" don't always have to come before a person / object in a sentence. To avoid repetition, they can replace it altogether. In each example below, the second sentence is much more natural.
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
AUDIO: How much is it? It's eighteen pounds altogether.
Select the words that have a similar meaning to "That comes to...".
Fill in the gap using the audio.
Oh, ok. What about this one?
Hello, how may I help you?
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Can I have t[k]h[/k][k]i[/k][k]s[/k] dress, please?
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Great, thanks. [k]I'll take[/k] this one and that hat, please.
We already know the numbers zero to nine. Now let's learn them all the way up to 100 and use them to talk about price and age.
We are now going to learn some expressions that are useful when shopping.
This expression is close in meaning to "Do you have...?".
Great. Do you have it in a different colour?
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Click on the word that refers to something nearby.
You can say this to find out the price of something.
Click on the words that refer to things that are further away.
Type the number you hear in the audio.
Right. Follow me. How about this one?
Select the word you could use before "shop".
You can also say "Do you have any...?". This expression is similar in meaning to "Do you sell...?".
I'm looking for a white shirt.
alternative_values: I am looking for a white shirt.
I am looking for a white shirt

en.value: Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
To ask about the price you can say "How much is it?" or "How much is this?".
We use "those" to refer to things / people that are further away.

We use "this", "that", "these" and "those" to talk about specific objects / people. First let's focus on "this" and "that". "This" refers to something that is nearby, and "that" usually refers to something that is further away.
We ask this to find out the price of something
Did you notice that we add the ending "-teen" to numbers 13 to 19?
The dress is [k]£35[/k] (thirty-five pounds) and the shirt is [k]£19[/k] (nineteen pounds).
Here's a recap of how we use "this", "that", "these" and "those".
